awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Resilience and Recovery among Ukrainian Small Business Owners
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will enhance of our understanding of how entrepreneurs cope with crisis and loss as well as how various resilience factors can facilitate recovery and rebuilding in communities disrupted by war or other disasters. Knowledge from this project will significantly inform the development of future support for entrepreneurs who experience trauma.

The project will assess and track the well-being and coping processes of Ukrainian small business owners displaced by war. Specifically, it will assess personality and social factors associated with resilience as well as the nature of the trauma and loss they experienced. Participants will be tracked over the course of a year and assessed on their current well-being, coping strategies, and future plans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to study the psychological and situational factors associated with how Ukrainian small business owners responded to being displaced or having their livelihoods threatened by the Russinan invasion of Ukraine in 2002. In particular, we were interested in investigating how entrepreneurial activity itself may help individuals with their psychological recovery from war trauma. The data for this study was collected across three waves across 2022-2024.  Across these time points, we were able to collect longitudinal data on 565 entrepreneurs. We collected data concerning the nature of the business they had before the war started, whether they had restarted new business, whether (and where) they had moved as a result of the war, the extent of trauma and violence they had personally experienced during the war, their coping styles, their personality traits, how much social support was available to them, and a number of measures concerning their mental health and well-being.

Our results suggested that individuals who were displaced or who had relocated during the war were more likely to start new business ventures and that older individuals were less likely to start new ventures. Individuals with high levels of psychological resilience were more likely to start new ventures while those who had greater financial resources at the beginning of the crisis were more likely to try to keep their existing ventures going. In terms of mental health outcomes, we found that it was positively associated with the amount of combat trauma that individuals experienced, but negatively associated with psychological resilience, age, and having more social support. In terms of personality traits, both Ambition and Sociability were associated with less mental health distress, but preexisting personality disorders were typically associated with increased levels of reported distress.

As the first longitudinal study of personality and mental health to take place within an active warzone, the present study represented a unique opportunity to understand the processes related to both new venture creation and individual resilience and recovery as they unfolded. Consequently, the results of this study will shed new light on how individuals, and entrepreneurs in particular, respond to crisis situations as well as the resources, both psychological and situational, that can be used to more successfully weather a crisis situation. It is hoped that the results of the present study will be useful for informing government policy concerning disaster relief and refugee crises moving forward. 

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2024
Modified by: Melissa S Cardon
